title: CIP-007: System Security Management
mission: Keep critical OT systems secure, monitored, and access-controlled so cyber issues are prevented, detected early, and contained.

why: CIP-007 keeps OT cyber assets hardened so reliability and safety are not disrupted by preventable attacks.
It sets rules for services, patches, malware prevention, monitoring, accounts, and remote access.
Every role touches these controls: operators see changes first, admins configure them, security monitors them, and compliance validates evidence.
highlights: Applies to BES Cyber Systems, PACS workstations, HMIs, servers, and jump hosts.
Requires documented procedures, not just tools.
Evidence must show the activity actually happened within the stated timeframe.

focus: Spot unexpected behavior on HMIs or control panels and report quickly.
Confirm maintenance and remote sessions are scheduled and visible.
Avoid introducing media or changes without approvals.
Maintain baselines, patch plans, and account hygiene for OT assets.
Coordinate with operations before service or patch changes.
Capture evidence as you work to simplify audits.
Tune detections for OT context and monitor remote access paths.
Investigate anomalies with operations before containment actions.
Ensure anti-malware and SIEM tooling respects OT performance limits.
Verify control evidence is collected at the required frequency.
Ensure procedures reflect what teams actually do.
Validate approvals for exceptions, deferrals, and emergency access.

rules: Answer only for what you know and do; avoid speculating about systems you do not own.
Reference documented procedures, tickets, or screenshots when responding to auditors.
If you do not know an answer, state that you will retrieve the evidence instead of guessing.
Keep responses concise and aligned to the control requirement being asked.

examples.prompt: How do you make sure patches are evaluated on time?
examples.bad: We usually get to them when things slow down.
examples.good: We review vendor advisories monthly, log decisions in the patch tracker, and schedule installs during approved maintenance windows.

examples.prompt: Who can enable a new service on an HMI?
examples.bad: Anyone on the team if they need to.
examples.good: Only system administrators with approved change tickets can enable services, and each change has a recorded business justification.

examples.prompt: What happens when you see repeated login failures?
examples.bad: We just reset the account and move on.
examples.good: We follow the security event runbook: confirm source, check SIEM alerts, and document the investigation with the action taken.

overview.goal: Only required ports, services, and software are enabled; everything else is disabled or removed.
overview.why: Reduces attack surface and keeps OT hosts predictable for operators.

overview.goal: OT patches and security updates are evaluated and applied on a defined cycle without disrupting operations.
overview.why: Limits exploit windows and aligns vendors, change control, and maintenance windows.

overview.goal: Malware prevention is deployed, tuned, and monitored on all applicable Cyber Assets.
overview.why: Stops common malware, USB-borne threats, and lateral movement into critical control systems.

overview.goal: Security events are logged, correlated, and triaged with documented responses.
overview.why: Allows early detection of misuse or compromise before it impacts reliability.

overview.goal: Accounts, passwords, and sessions follow least privilege, rotation, and timeout rules.
overview.why: Prevents stale or shared credentials from enabling unauthorized changes.

overview.goal: Interactive remote access into ESPs is controlled, monitored, and brokered through secure paths.
overview.why: Limits exposure from external connections and enforces jump host protections.

roles.System Administrator: Maintain golden builds and patch calendars; keep evidence packages ready for spot-checks.

r1.OT Operator: Validate that new services don't change control screens or latency. Report slowdowns immediately.
r1.System Administrator: Baseline ports, remove unused software, and document deviations with approvals.
r1.Security Team: Review scans for rogue services and investigate unauthorized listeners quickly.
r1.Compliance/Audit: Check inventories match configurations and decommission plans are tracked.

r2.OT Operator: Know when patch windows happen so you can monitor system behavior afterward.
r2.System Administrator: Track vendor advisories, test patches offline, and schedule installs with change control.
r2.Security Team: Prioritize fixes tied to exploitable CVEs and document compensating measures when delays occur.
r2.Compliance/Audit: Ensure evaluations and install decisions are recorded with dates and risk justifications.

r3.OT Operator: Do not insert unknown media. Notify security if malware prompts appear or scans impact controls.
r3.System Administrator: Keep signatures updated and exclusions tuned so protection doesn't break OT applications.
r3.Security Team: Centralize malware alerts and verify quarantines or blocks are logged and escalated.
r3.Compliance/Audit: Confirm anti-malware coverage and that exception reviews have approvals and expiry dates.

r4.OT Operator: Report unusual alarms or repeated login prompts—they may correlate to security events.
r4.System Administrator: Forward critical logs to the SIEM and validate time sync so correlation works.
r4.Security Team: Own detection rules, triage playbooks, and evidence of follow-up actions.
r4.Compliance/Audit: Check that log retention, access, and review frequencies match documented procedures.

r5.OT Operator: Use named accounts; avoid sharing passwords on shift. Lock screens when stepping away.
r5.System Administrator: Enforce password complexity, disable dormant accounts, and document shared credential approvals.
r5.Security Team: Monitor account anomalies and privileged access use. Investigate repeated lockouts.
r5.Compliance/Audit: Validate user attestation records and that access removal is timed with role changes.

r6.OT Operator: Confirm remote sessions are scheduled and visible; challenge unscheduled activity.
r6.System Administrator: Maintain jump hosts, MFA, and session recording for remote connections.
r6.Security Team: Monitor remote access logs, alerts, and ensure approvals exist for sessions.
r6.Compliance/Audit: Review that remote access follows procedure and recordings are retained.

scenarios.System Administrator: Map each scenario to change tickets and verify rollback plans are ready.
scenarios.Security Team: Use scenarios to practice containment steps and communication with operations.

checklist.OT Operator: Use the checklist to quickly verify consoles, alerts, and remote access sessions look normal before shift.
checklist.System Administrator: Treat it as a maintenance ready-reference for patches, accounts, and services.

checklist.Compliance/Audit: Confirm evidence artifacts line up with the checklist cadence.

requirements.title: R1 – Ports & Services
requirements.purpose: Only necessary ports, services, and default accounts are enabled on OT Cyber Assets.
risks: Rogue services create backdoors or increase latency on HMIs and controllers.
Default credentials or unneeded software allow easy exploitation.
Unexpected network listeners disrupt deterministic network behavior.
good: Baseline of approved services per asset type with documented business need.
Regular service reviews against configuration baselines and vulnerability scans.
Disabled defaults and removal of unused software after commissioning.
evidence: Service inventory with date of last review and approver.
Screenshots or exports of disabled ports/services settings.
Change tickets for any new service enabling or software installs.
mistakes: Leaving vendor diagnostic services running after maintenance windows.
Allowing temporary firewall exceptions to become permanent.
Not updating baselines when assets are rebuilt or replaced.
quickChecks: Spot-check listeners on HMIs for only documented ports.
Confirm removed software is also off the startup list.
Verify service accounts are disabled when not in use.
done: All active services have an owner, purpose, and approval.
Scan results match the approved baseline with no unexplained listeners.
Default or vendor accounts are disabled or renamed with strong credentials.

requirements.title: R2 – Patch Management
requirements.purpose: Evaluate, test, and apply security patches for applicable OT components on a defined schedule.
risks: Unpatched systems expose known exploits used in ransomware campaigns.
Unplanned patching can interrupt control applications or HMIs.
Skipped evaluations leave gaps without documented compensating measures.
good: Patch calendar aligned to maintenance windows and vendor guidance.
Lab testing or staging before production deployment with rollback steps.
Documented risk decision when patches are deferred, plus interim safeguards.
evidence: Patch evaluation logs showing vendor notices, applicability, and decisions.
Install records with dates, approvers, and verification notes.
List of compensating measures when patches are delayed.
mistakes: Applying IT images to OT assets without vendor validation.
Missing firmware updates on embedded devices tracked outside normal patch tools.
No record of what failed in testing, leading to repeated outages.
quickChecks: Confirm last evaluation date is within the required window.
Review rollback plans before each deployment.
Verify offline assets are patched when returned to service.
done: All applicable patches evaluated within the defined timeframe.
Successful installs documented with post-checks and no lingering compensating measures.
Deferred patches have risk acceptance, expiry date, and tracking to closure.

requirements.title: R3 – Malware Prevention
requirements.purpose: Deploy and manage malware prevention that fits OT constraints.
risks: USB-borne malware or phishing payloads spread into control networks.
Overly aggressive scans cause latency or crash vendor applications.
Disabled signatures leave assets blind to new threats.
good: OT-tuned anti-malware with exclusions validated by vendors.
Signature updates controlled through allowlisted repositories or manual updates.
Alerting integrated into SOC/SIEM with clear response playbooks.
evidence: List of protected assets with agent version and last signature update.
Approval records for scan exclusions and schedules.
Alert tickets showing investigation and resolution.
mistakes: Leaving isolated devices without compensating controls when agents cannot install.
Using IT scan schedules that overlap with batch runs or tuning events.
Not documenting USB scanning results for field media.
quickChecks: Verify signatures are current on HMIs and jump hosts.
Confirm removable media is scanned before connection.
Check that quarantined files have follow-up tickets.
done: All applicable assets have protection or documented exceptions.
Updates and scans run on the approved cadence without affecting operations.
Alerts are routed, acknowledged, and resolved per playbook timelines.

requirements.title: R4 – Security Event Monitoring
requirements.purpose: Log and review security events that could indicate misuse or compromise.
risks: Undetected failed logins become credential stuffing or brute force.
Clock drift breaks correlation and hides lateral movement.
Critical alarms are buried in noise without triage rules.
good: Time-synchronized logs forwarded to a central collector with SIEM rules.
Documented review frequency and on-call escalation paths.
Runbooks for common alerts such as repeated lockouts or new services detected.
evidence: Log forwarding configs and screenshots proving events arrive at the SIEM.
Alert review records with timestamp, analyst, and action taken.
Time sync (NTP) status for critical assets.
mistakes: Letting storage fill up and silently dropping logs.
Not monitoring remote access events from jump hosts.
quickChecks: Verify SIEM shows fresh events from HMIs and jump hosts.
Spot-check time sync status on critical servers.
Confirm weekly reviews occurred and tickets are closed.
done: Critical event sources are connected and time-synced.
Alerts have clear owners and documented response steps.
Evidence exists for scheduled reviews and escalations.

requirements.title: R5 – Account Management
requirements.purpose: Manage authentication, passwords, and access revocation for shared and individual accounts.
risks: Stale accounts remain active after contractors leave.
Weak passwords or no lockouts allow brute-force entry.
good: Named accounts for operators and administrators with least privilege.
Password complexity, rotation, and session timeout configured for OT systems.
Documented process for emergency or shared accounts with approvals and logs.
evidence: User lists mapped to roles with last login dates.
Password policy settings and lockout thresholds screenshots.
Deprovisioning tickets tied to role changes or contractor departures.
mistakes: Leaving vendor or contractor accounts active after work completes.
No session timeout on shared consoles in control rooms.
Weak service account passwords reused across devices.
quickChecks: Spot-check for shared logins still in use on HMIs.
Verify last login dates for dormant accounts.
Confirm session lock is enabled on jump hosts.
done: Only approved accounts exist with mapped owners and access levels.
Password and lockout policies enforced per standard.
Access removals are documented within required timelines.

requirements.title: R6 – Interactive Remote Access
requirements.purpose: Control and monitor remote interactive access into Electronic Security Perimeters.
risks: Direct connections bypass jump hosts and evade monitoring.
Unrecorded sessions hide what changes were made.
Weak MFA or shared credentials allow external compromise.
good: All remote access terminates on managed jump hosts with MFA and session recording.
Approvals and scheduling are required before sessions begin.
Session logs reviewed and alerts generated for unexpected access.
evidence: Jump host configuration showing MFA, recording, and timeouts.
Access request tickets with approvals and session IDs.
Reports of remote access sessions reviewed with findings.
mistakes: Allowing vendor direct VPN into control networks.
Recording disabled to improve performance with no compensating control.
Not revoking jump host access after project closeout.
quickChecks: Check current session list on jump hosts for expected activity.
Verify MFA prompts fire for each connection.
Review last week's remote access report for anomalies.
done: Remote access only through approved brokers with MFA and recording.
Sessions are authorized, logged, and reviewed.
Emergency access is time-bound and documented.

scenarios.situation: A vendor requests quick access to update HMI graphics outside the change window.
scenarios.action: Route the request through the jump host with MFA, create a change ticket, and schedule during the approved window or apply compensating controls.
scenarios.why: Unauthorized or unscheduled remote changes can bypass monitoring and introduce errors.

scenarios.situation: Operators notice a new service listening on port 8080 after a maintenance weekend.
scenarios.action: Compare against the approved service baseline, disable if not required, and document in change control with security review.
scenarios.why: Unknown listeners expand the attack surface and may indicate unauthorized installs.

scenarios.situation: Patch testing shows a control app crash on a new OS update.
scenarios.action: Record the failure, defer deployment, implement compensating controls, and retest with vendor guidance.
scenarios.why: Deploying untested patches risks outages; deferral must be justified and tracked.

scenarios.situation: SIEM alerts on repeated failed logins to a jump host during off-hours.
scenarios.action: Escalate per playbook, verify MFA attempts, check for correlated activity, and lock accounts if needed.
scenarios.why: Early response prevents credential guessing from becoming an intrusion.

questions.prompt: What is the primary goal of R1 – Ports & Services?
options: Ensure every service is updated weekly
Limit enabled ports/services to only what the asset requires
Block all inbound traffic
Allow vendors to run diagnostics anytime
feedback: Updates matter, but R1 focuses on limiting enabled services.
Correct. R1 reduces the attack surface by only allowing required services.
Blocking all inbound traffic is not practical for OT operations.
Diagnostics must be scheduled and approved, not open-ended.

questions.prompt: When a patch is deferred after failing testing, what should happen?
options: Ignore the patch until the next cycle
Deploy it anyway in production
Document compensating measures and track a retest date
Remove the asset from service permanently
feedback: Deferrals require documentation, not silence.
Deploying a failing patch risks outages.
Correct. Record the reason, compensating measures, and plan to retest.
Removal is rarely feasible and not required when deferring.

questions.prompt: Which control best supports R3 – Malware Prevention in OT?
options: Unrestricted full disk scans during production runs
Signature updates and exclusions validated with vendors
Relying only on perimeter firewalls
Disabling anti-malware to improve performance
feedback: Scans must be tuned, not unrestricted.
Correct. Updates plus vendor-approved exclusions keep protection effective and safe for OT.
Perimeter firewalls alone don't stop USB-borne or lateral malware.
Disabling protections violates R3 and increases risk.

questions.prompt: What makes event monitoring effective under R4?
options: Saving logs locally without review
Forwarding logs to a SIEM with time sync and review playbooks
Deleting old logs to free space monthly
Only monitoring office network events
feedback: Unreviewed local logs miss threats.
Correct. Central collection with correlation, time sync, and triage is required.
Log retention is required; deletion without retention policy breaks evidence.
OT assets must be monitored, not just IT.

questions.prompt: Which action aligns with R5 – Account Management?
options: Sharing one admin account for all contractors
Keeping default vendor accounts enabled for convenience
Enforcing session timeouts and removing accounts when projects end
Allowing unlimited password retries
feedback: Shared accounts reduce accountability.
Default accounts must be disabled or secured.
Correct. Timeouts and timely removals are core to R5.
Lockouts are required to deter brute force.

questions.prompt: For R6, which remote access pattern is acceptable?
options: Direct VPN into the control network using shared credentials
Jump host with MFA, recorded sessions, and pre-approved access
Remote desktop without monitoring during off-hours
Personal laptops connecting directly to controllers
feedback: Direct VPN without controls violates R6.
Correct. Remote access must be brokered, authenticated with MFA, and monitored.
Sessions must be monitored and approved, not silent.
Unmanaged endpoints should not connect to controllers.

questions.prompt: Why does CIP-007 require role-based reviews of services and accounts?
options: To satisfy HR policy
To align technical changes with operational needs and accountability
To slow down change approvals
Because audits happen monthly
feedback: CIP-007 is not about HR policy.
Correct. Aligning roles ensures changes are necessary, safe, and traceable.
Efficiency is good; slowing approvals is not the goal.
Frequency of audits is not the primary reason.

questions.prompt: What should operators do if anti-malware quarantines a file during shift?
options: Ignore it and continue
Disable anti-malware to restore the file
Notify security, capture the alert details, and confirm OT processes remain stable
Delete the application to be safe
feedback: Quarantines must be reviewed.
Disabling protection increases risk.
Correct. Report, document, and ensure operations stay stable.
Deletion without analysis can harm operations.

questions.prompt: When is the Operational Checklist unlocked?
options: After visiting any requirement page
After passing the Knowledge Check
After downloading resources
Immediately on first visit
feedback: Completion alone does not unlock it.
Correct. Passing the quiz shows understanding before using the checklist.
Resources are optional and not a gate.
It is intentionally gated.

Prevent.item: Verify only approved ports/services are running on HMIs and servers
Confirm signature updates succeeded on all applicable assets
Ensure remote access jump hosts enforce MFA and session recording
Validate patch evaluations are completed within the defined window

Detect.item: Review SIEM alerts for failed logins and new services
Check NTP/time sync status on logging sources
Confirm anti-malware alerts have tickets with disposition

Respond.item: Verify rollback plans exist for upcoming patches
Ensure accounts disabled within required timeframe after role changes
Document investigations for remote access anomalies

policies: Remote Access Procedure for ESP Assets
tools: Patch management or vendor advisory portal

Schedule a spot-check of your assets against R1–R6.
Log into the SIEM to confirm your sources are still reporting.
